24797554.review:
I just reached the end of the early-access portion of this game while streaming last night. There are apparently a few quests I didn’t complete yet, so I might go back and do those at some point.

This game is not only beautiful to look at, but really immersive. The only music that happens is on menu/dialogue screens (it’s all text dialogue, which I’m actually fine with) and during chase sequences when you need to get away and hide. This means that 90% of the time, you’re listening to ambiance and action noises. Fire crackling, cicadas chirping, guard footsteps, etc. This is actually very good sound design, since you wouldn’t want music all the time when you’re trying to listen for things in the game world.

The game also DEMANDS exploration, as there are some things that are really hidden away. Hell, I actually had to look up something at one point (very hard to do on an obscure early-access game) because it involved going into a dangerous area, hopping a wall to a rooftop, and finding a way into the rafters. The game is a stealth-based RPG, which normally isn’t my thing, but I love the world they’ve created, and the characters are really interesting. One character you meet is a big bag of mystery that I really hope is explored more in the final release. There’s one thing about him I’m extremely curious about now.

It’s really interesting that this game was put together by just five people, the studio head being a former DreamWorks animator, and it shows. The animations are fluid and feel natural. When Tilo is looking at someone or something he can interact with, he’ll actually look up/down at it, and tilt his head curiously. If you walk into a wall, he’ll turn either right or left instead of just standing with his face buried in a stone. If you need to get onto something, he’ll actually crawl onto it instead of just jumping high enough to get onto it. When you interact with an item, he’ll actually reach out to grab the item.

Subtle little details like this just make all the difference in pulling you into the world. The lighting effects for the day/night cycle are just amazing, and affects how well you can see things. Not just the darkness, either. The bright dawn light can obscure your vision at certain angles. The game does have its glitches here and there, but it’s early-access alpha still, so I can forgive them.

It won’t be for everyone, and it is pretty demanding on system requirements (my GTX 670 barely makes the minimum specs, and I get frame rate tanks in certain spots, primarily when transitioning between certain areas), but I definitely recommend it to any fans of the genre. If you want to help support them in building the final release and have a strong enough PC (or plan to buy/build one in the near future), consider buying into the Steam early-access. I, for one, am glad I did. It was worth the three-year wait.

24759354.review:
I played this live on twitch(dot)tv/z32o
As of Aug 1st 2016 my thoughts on the game:

A game that focuses a lot on exploration, Ghost of a Tale is the masterpiece of SeithCG and a couple of his friends.

You'll be amazed at the character design of Tilo (the main protagonist) and how he moves. It is VERY hard not to squeal just by looking at it.

What this game presents in order of emphasis:
- Exploration: many corners hide collectibles, cloth pieces or lore tidbits
- Costumes: alters your stats. Use different clothing according to the situation
- Stealth: the enemies are Rats, big and clumsy, can be outrun if you are quick
- Lore and Story: There's a story behind it and you'll discover as you play
- Day and Night cycle: Some stuff only happen at night, while others happen during the day

What can be improved:
- Enemy AI: needs more improvement as the rats have predictable movements and static speed
- Voiceover: there are some parts that would shine if a voiceover was used, when Tilo sings for example. Even Banjo-Kazooie sounds or Okami sounds would be awesome.


Overall it's a solid game if you like exploration based games!

Your first playthough of this should take you anywhere between 8h to 16h depending on if you use the hint system or not, and if you choose to collect everything.

i can not wait for this game to be finished so please buy it to ensure that it does get finished :)

現時点ではステルス型のアクションADVです。
色々なキャラクター達と会話しクエストを貰い、主にアイテムを拾ったりしてクエストを達成します。
ある程度英語がわからないと、少し解りにくいかも。とりあえず色々拾いあつめれば問題はありませんが。

鍵がかかっているドアがあれば、鍵はどこにあるんだろうとか
目的のアイテムはどこにあるんだろうとか、それを見つける要素が大きいかもしれません。
わりと見落としがちな所にあったりします。
ｖ1.49では、この辺りだろうと行ってもアイテムが無かったりしましたが
現在は修正されている所もあります。

ステルスといっても、見つかってしまってもある程度引き離せばオブジェに隠れやりすごせるので
進みたい所へは見つかって逃げて進んでも良い感じです。
ある程度食べ物を拾って食べておけば、体力が増え走れる距離も増えるので楽になります。
ただ、この作業の繰り返しになる部分はあります。
まだ行ける範囲が少ないのでお使い感は強いと思います。
ここはこうしたら進めるのかとか、ここにこれは落ちてたのかとか、そういう発見は楽しいです。
後、ろうそくや木の棒などの一部の消費アイテムは無限に拾える場所もあったりします。

色々服などを拾い装備をすると見た目も変化するので、見た目もかわいいし能力がアップしたり
ADVとしての役割もあります。

ゲームのセーブはＮＰＣと会話した時ａｕｔｏ　ｓａｖｅと表示された時と、
安全な状態でオブジェに身を隠した時に任意でできるようになっています。

今後の展開が楽しみです。日本語も対応するとうれしいなと思う。

細かい修正も進んでいるのでバグによるハマリなども少なくなっていっていると思います。

Прошел год, как я опубликовал обзор следующего содержания:

""Игра обещает быть хорошей - забавный персонаж (надоели оркоэльфогномы), интересные локации, красивая картинка. Сюжет банален, но любителям почитать о том, каково житье-бытье у разумных мышей автор много чего насочинял, с учетом нижесказанного правда...

Всего две не очень больших локации. Две. Всего. Баги вроде нефункционирующей клавиатуры после очередного патча (wsad и полмышки явно недостаточно для комфортной игры). Про мелкие недочеты упоминать не буду. Да, я знаю, что это ранний доступ, но версия игры 1.63... По моему мнению, игру в таком состоянии сложно назвать даже альфой... это какая то демо версия для будущего издателя, а может быть попытка собрать денег и обойтись без оного.

В настоящий момент рекомендую к покупке только тем, кому не жалко платить за обещания чего то большего в будущем. Искренне надеюсь, что разработчик все таки допечет эту булочку, рецепт которой выглядит очень соблазнительно.""

И что же изменилось за год, что у нас тут в патчноутах написано? А почти что ничего - разработчик в основном правит всяческие ошибки. В игре как было полторы локации, так и осталось. Учитывая, что период жизни игр с момента их анонса 3-5 лет, то не рекомендую тратить на эту игру время и уж тем более деньги. Если она когда то и выйдет, то попросту затеряется на фоне более расторопных конкурентов, и будет очередным устаревшим еще до выхода долгостроем. Тут либо переоценили свои силы, либо пытаются обмануть - проходите мимо.

24721415.review:
This game absolutely needs to be given more praise and attention than it is given right now, and deffinitely deserves your money. 

The setting, Old yet fresh. The characters, bleak yet animated. the mouse, realistic yet FLUFFING CUTE! *SQWEEAAAL*

This game, or what is shown of it in it's early access form, is like the books of Redwall or Tale of Despereaux come to life in a stealth, action adventure RPG. Really it's a beautiful work of wit, writing, and imagination, which is serious in tone, but simple, light-hearted, and enjoyable in execution. It is a game with a heart, which is rare in today's world. It's a game that you could find yourself coming back to looking for the small things that you may have missed and the stories that have yet to be told. The land of rats, mice, frogs, and spiders tells a medievil tale of a mouse attempting to reunite with a lost loved one, and it tells it in a thought out world where everything has a past and a reason for existing. 

The gameplay is simplistic, but varied, and hopefully with the introduction of combat and greater amounts of items and functions, something that could make a mark on how games should be made. Stealth is tough, but never impossible, but also never too easy, puzzles are not always explained, clues are not always obvious, and the density of a dialog between two rodents is never too dull. When you must find a key, you never have to look to far, but you may just as well miss it completely. The rats feel imposing and vigilant with their size and strength, but are never above being tricked, or eluded.  Fetch quests are never too dull with "go here, get that," but are instead hunts and puzzles, and expect wit. Sometimes you may talk yourself into getting an item from another character, and sometimes you may talk yourself out of getting one. Even tedious backtracking is still found to be exciting, allowing you to go to those unknown places that are teased before you that then eventually open to contain more world and treasure. 

My criticisms that should be addressed though are few but key if I do say so myself. Since it is in early access and isn't completely finished, I would like to share some of these and see if anyone else could agree with it, and take the opportunity to get them changed. First, jumping, and platforming, should deffinitely recieve some more testing, as you are just as likely to land or grab onto a ledge as you are to fall or not grab it, and this should definitely be tightend up or at least made more forgiving. Also, a minor irritance to relate, maybe make the roofs and other surfaces less bumpy or prone to being slid on, in order to give a greater sense of control and dexterity. The second to address, is speed. While nobody would expect a small mouse in a full suit of platemail armor to be speedy, climbing ladders, and ledges could use some speeding up, or an optional sprinting version of these two activites, that otherwise seem slightly teadious when running around the levels which are deep in detail and vertical in design. 

Overall, as it is in it's current state, I would definitely say that it is worth the price of admision, and the game is excellent for its depth, detail, character, charm, gameplay, and RPG, stealth, and action elements, but certainly isn't a very good platformer or the next Mirror's Edge or Dying Light. Regardless, if you are a fan of Fable, Dark Souls, The Elder Scrolls, Thief or non-RPG games like Banjo-Kazooie, Jak and Daxter, or Assassin's Creed, I'm sure you could find something you'll love, in this big ambitious world compressed into a small package that is [u] Ghost of a Tale [/u]

24685953.review:
Basically this is Redwall Abbey: The Game, only with a bit of MGS, Hitman and Zelda.

You explore the world, hide from the guards (there is no combat system, at least not yet) look for the secrets and do all this familiar adventure-RPG routine.

- Main gameplay is just fine. Stealth works, game is not crazy-hard and violent and sutable for a child. 

- Interface is a bit messy, but manageable. Game has a strong stealth epmhasis that suits the setting very well, you're a little mouse after all.

- Also like in Hitman you have suits that can disguise you, but like in Zelda you have to explore the world to obtain them first.

- Level design is a bit broken (Sewers), but very logical and very connected. Once again - like Zelda.

But this is all poetry, let's tell the tale!

- For Unity 5-game GoT looks and feels amazing. Animations are smooth and the main character movements is something like a Cute Drug. Idle animations is the best i ever saw in RPGs. Believe me, this game is beyound cute. If you have a wife (or waifu, hehe) or a girlfriend who loves rodents - this is your NO 1 purchase.

- FPS is steady on my rig and I haven't  encountered any game-breaking bugs so far (few collision problems is fine, it's an Early Access game after all)

- Plays nicely with mouse (no pun intended) and keyboard. But works better with XO controller.

So far this is the most "game-ready" project that i ever had in my Early Access library. Unlike DayZ or We Happy Few, right now Ghost of a Tale plays, feels and looks like a fully-fledged AAA-title (on a slight budget). Yup, the game is short on RPG-lenght content and voiceover would definitely be a nice touch, but even for now you can buy this game and complete it from start to finish without any regrets.

Yes, some elments like stealth-meter and inventory management are in dire need of tweaking, but nothing horrible. Hopefully they will be patched.

My only problem with tha game right now: it ends. I hope our money from Early Access will go to expand the title and bring the voice actors who will gift a Green Fire of Life to this very exciting setting.

Also the game right now is more plot-ready and playable than Fallout 4 was on release, which is very-very funny.

Mouses 1: Rad-rats 0. Fine by me,

24683556.review:
Early Access Watcher Reviews Ghost of a Tale

Update Version: Build 1.63

Disclosure: This game copy was bought by the reviewer.

"Welcome to Dwindling Heights Keep, young minstrel. You have been sent here for one reason or another (wish to keep the story somewhat spoiler free), and will find our prison to be most comfortable. While you are here, you will be expected to behave and listen to the commands of the guards patrolling outside your cell. If you refuse, I can assure the guards can see to your swift passage into the afterlife. Should you wish to press forward, you might discover a beautiful adventure that will either see you taking center stage in a quest to find a missing love or merely a forgotten whimper in the wind." Now with that out of the way, we are here to answer one simple question: is Ghost of a Tale worth the price of admission?

The visual aesthetic is gorgeous. Texture detail in the walls and floors really stands out in the form of cracks and moss. Character models for the mice are adorable with great attention to the clothing features. Rats look outright menacing and garner dented armor. Lighting effects are still a work in progress (way to dark at night), but the sunny atmosphere and proper shadow features in the jail reflect the level of care this developer seems to be taking with the overall look. Animation quality is high grade the times it is used, but it still needs refinement for certain actions (such as level operation). Sound plays a big role in the game and something as simple as armor clanking adds special detail to the ambiance. Music is very soothing outside of encounters, which sees the volume ramped up in the form of the horn section. The hit of the anvil, the scurrying of hasty feet and something simple as climbing furniture is satisfying to hear, but there is a lack of sounds for other actions. If anything though, the visual quality is the best attribute for this game.

The story is unfinished, but the characters and backstory available offer a humbling experience. The main character, Tilo, must find the help of a couple of rats, a few mice and a rather rude frog. Each character is somewhat fleshed out during dialog, which is cleverly written. Certain key information mentioned in dialog can be further explored in foot notes and helps with the world building. Quests are also present in the game and completing them opens up new quests and also fleshes out the characters more. Outfit pieces are also scattered around the keep that, if worn in front of certain characters, open up more dialog options that further expand on the lore and just look adorable on Tilo. The content available was pleasant to read (especially some optional ballads), but I was able to finish everything in a few hours (includes finding the roses, beetles, quests). It left me wanting more, which is a point in favor of the game's writing, but not for the discussion of cost vs value. 

There is no combat, period. Every encounter must be dealt with in a stealthy manner. Rats will patrol in a choreographed paths and you will need to get past them using hiding spots and timing. If you are seen, you must sprint your way to a hiding spot (barrel, chests, cupboards) to escape the view of these pesky rodents. If you are hit, you can be knocked out unconscious to and choked by the rat (prompting a quick time event to escape the grip). Bottles can be used to get a rat's attention and make them move to a spot outside of the path. Other enemies exist in the form of insects and need to be out run to avoid damage. It is barebones in terms of strategy and it falls back to a glaring issue I noticed: the AI is lackluster.

Rat patrols have been a mixed bag in terms of functionality. I have seen rats get stuck into doorways (the actual doorframe, not stuck in the space) and seen rats get stuck in alert mode outside hiding spots when they should be de initializing. I even had three rats looking at me in a room and managed to still hide in a cupboard. More shockingly enough, I just hopped onto the bed in the room just inside the entrance of the jail and managed to appear hidden. The AI really needs some work if it hopes to present a challenge in an environment that seems to be easily manipulated by running past guards and makes sneaking relatively useless.

Controlling the game with a mouse and keyboard was helped with the patch released earlier today, but it is still preferable to play using a controller. The camera is rotated using the motion of the mouse and can become a real nuisance, especially during chase sequences. Frame rate drops do happen in certain areas of the game and the inventory has a chance to become unresponsive. The guard armor set also fails to traverse through certain doorways and stairways, making it rather inconvenient for both movement and losing full health to change out of the set. It is, after all, in development, but it is still good to address what you might expect.

If there had to be one word to describe Ghost of a Tale, it would have to be ambitious. The presentation values are very high quality for something in early access and doesn't have as many optimization issues. That being said, the overbearing issue is with the lack of content currently present in the game. I wish I could say otherwise, but the price of the game just isn't worth twos X a half hours of exploration. I will come back in six months to see how the game has evolved and eagerly await to see more of the story.

Pros
- Gorgeous, gorgeous scenery
- Characters and world building are great thus far

Cons
- Controls are finicky on mouse and keyboard, best suited for a controller
- AI is pathetic, making stealth pointless
- Overall content is relatively short

24674447.review:
Charming, witty, and full of polish. Tilo may be escaping from jail, but the world he inhabits is unbelievably rich. Each character has their own motivations, personalities, and quirks. You are never quite sure who to trust, or if you should even trust at all. The gameplay is challenging, the puzzles are unique and test observational skills. But perhaps the greatest draw is that you can go through this adventure as you see fit.

You choose who to be nice to, you choose who you can scam. The consequences of your actions are merely moral - and not shoved down on you. One quick example, I revisited the frog early in the game dressed as his captain. I could have told him the truth that his captain, and friend, was dead. But instead I lied and continued the farce. I was then able to retrieve the item I was looking for from him, and was also able to get five florences in the process through the scam. I don't know if this is the inevitable outcome, but it felt as though I made the decisions leading there. And the game didn't punish me for it. I had to live with knowing that I lied to an old frog who never truly got to say goodbye to his friend - and the only consequence was one that I put on myself. This type of moral choice is only capable via this medium, and it is done with artistic grace. Other games that offer choices typically hold your feet to the fire in a black and white situation of good vs evil. 'Ghost of a Tale' does not paint morality for you - it makes you discover it for yourself. And that is just ONE example of the countless choices I had to make with the NPCs.

Gameplay is satisfying, and honestly well done. The UI is fantastic for this, and limiting the stamina on current health pool is ingenious. The stealth mechanic is intuitive, and works better than the majority of stealth games I have ever seen. All of this – and no combat. Yes, you can knock some guards out – but it is often wasteful and more strategic to play it safe.

This isn’t to say the game doesn’t have room for improvement. There were a few times where I truly got stuck. The Sewer Key, for example, was particularly infuriating. I searched everywhere for that key. To find that it was in a second drawer early on in the game almost made me want to stop. A big part of what makes this game fun is the discovery and collection of things. But when they are hidden too well then things become taxing. Keys are the typical example here, but there are others. An improvement I would make would be to have important items slightly glow, or shimmer, in order to draw the players eye. Or, have the Blacksmith make them glow and show you exact locations if you do pay him. This is a major problem that needs to be addressed.

The other problem with the game is in fact with the Blacksmith. It is too easy to save, spend your money to hear what he has to say, then reload. I was able to hear everything he needed to say in a few minutes and never having to spend money. There is one quest that requires you to pay him, but figuring that out was resolved through more of trial and error than by game design.

Despite these few qualms I am in love with this game. I am more than satisfied with spending $20 for the 7 hours I have put into it – if this was all there was to the game I would be immensely satisfied. I want to know more about this world, its characters, history, and Tilo’s story.  Thank you for this amazing experience.

24668447.review:
Ok, so this is updated version of my first review, which was negative.
I have passed the game, with all the quests done and in about 2 hours (had to replay due to the bug).
There are tons of things you have to know, which the game doesn't tell you if you want to survive.
Lemme first write what I liked/disliked and then I will give you some tips:
good side:
+ Tons of secrets
+ Tons of disguises
+ Graphics
+ Tons of characters
+ Tons of collectables
+ Romantic story (a good story! not like some of those anime vn :I)
+ A disguise affects how NPCs are talking to you
+ Never had enough of florens for some reason
+ Constant big updates fixing most of the issues without making new
+ Sneaking is hard, but later it's easy to understand
+ Guard Suit - faggots were pissing me off
+ Plague Doctor Mask - <3

bad side:
- some minor bugs like being stuck on stairs etc
- FPS drops sometimes
- some people are reporting missing items, but it's constantly fixed
- can't really protect yourself, only with a bottle
- going back and forth through known places for one quest sometimes may be boring

There you got some tips:
1. You can knock down guards without helmet if you will headshot them with a bottle
2. Disguises increase your stamina/health
3. Buffs from disguises apply only if you have a full set
4. The detection meter of guards lowers if you stand still, not sneak
5. Listen to the dialogues, don't skip them
6. Thief disguise gives you more text with Gustio and Fatale, Pirate diguise with Pirate Frog and Guard set allows you to pass next to the guards unnoticed and even talk to them!
7. The Blacksmith can basically mark you every secret on your map for a few florens which you can find mostly in the sewers.

TL;DR:
8.5/10 - Good potential, some bugs and it lacks some things - but if the creators will guide it right - we may get a very cool game.

24665202.review:
Dieses ist das erste Spiel, zumindest abseits von Kickstarter, welches ich bereits im Early Access gekauft habe. Aber warum? Ein Impulskauf? Ein Versehen? Aus Mitleid? Mitnichten!
In diesem Fall haben mich tatsächlich alleine schon die unbewegten wie bewegten Bilder der zugehörigen Produktseite im Steam Store völlig in ihren Bann geschlagen. Nun zähle ich mich beileibe nicht zu den Personen, welche mit einem hübschen Äußeren allein zufriedenzustellen sind. Gelogen wäre es allerdings, wenn mir eine hübsche Hülle nicht zusagen würde. Schließlich ist es genau das, was einem zuerst ins Auge fällt.

Obwohl ein Indie-Titel, sind die Spielwelt und ihre tierischen Bewohner unglaublich detailliert und liebevoll gestaltet. Sie wären eines AAA-Titels würdig. Hinter der schönen Fassade verbirgt sich aber auch noch ein ganz formidables Action-Adventure alter Schule, ganz in der Machart eines The Legend of Zelda. Ihr verkörpert den kleinen Mäuserich Tilo, ein Barde, welcher durch einen Fauxpas einen Baron verärgert, welcher daraufhin seine Frau entführt. Tilo hingegen zog über Los und direkt ins Gefängnis, wo er dann auch zu Beginn des Spiels aufwacht. Nun gilt es natürlich, seine holde Maid zu befreien! Na, hoffentlich heißt es am Ende des fertigen Spiels nicht: "Thank you, Tilo! But your princess is in another castle!".

Aus allen Ecken und Enden strömt diese warme, gemütliche und lauschige Atmosphäre, welche mich an all die schöne Kinder- und Jugend-Fantasy der 1980er und frühen 1990er erinnert. Ich sehe in Ghost of a Tale nicht nur die erwachsene Version von Feivel der Mauswanderer, eine Prise Die unendliche Geschichte, sondern erkenne auch Parallelen zu Brian Jaques Redwall-Romanreihe. Die sehr realistisch anmutende Darstellung der Tiere weckt bei mir unweigerlich Gedanken an Filme wie Hexen, Hexen und deren handgearbeitete Masken und Puppen.

Einerseits kaum zu glauben, da Ghost of a Tale in der Hauptsache von nur einer Person, Lionel "Seith" Gallat, erschaffen wurde wird, andererseits hat genau diese Person lange Zeit als Künstler und Animator bei Filmen von Dreamworks mitgewirkt, doch später auch an Ich, einfach unverbesserlich sowie Der Lorax.

Bereits in dieser frühen Early Access-Fassung erwarten dich rund acht bis zehn Stunden Spielzeit, welche mit 26 Quests, zahlreichen sammelbaren Gegenständen sowie fünf NPCs gefüllt ist. Letztere dienen zur Interaktion, natürlich vornehmlich um dir besagte Quests zuzuschustern. Dabei gilt es ein recht weitläufiges Gefängnis zu erkunden, wobei es zunächst einmal aus der eigenen Zelle zu flüchten gilt. Dein Pfad führt dich durch Katakomben, die Kanalisation bis hinauf in den Hof. Neben den NPCs bevölkern Wachen das Gebiet, dessen Konfrontation du stets vermeiden solltest. Kämpfen ist keine Option, dafür umso mehr das Schleichen, Verstecken sowie Flüchten.

Ich liebe die Kombination aus Schleichen, Rollenspiel sowie Action-Adventure. Rollenspiel? Ja, doch das manifestiert sich bis dato hauptsächlich im trainieren einiger, weniger Fertigkeiten sowie der Möglichkeit, unterschiedliche Kleidungs- und Rüstungsteile zu tragen. Letztere dienen nicht nur euren Attributen, sondern sie sind zudem unglaublich süß anzusehen (u.a. Dieb, Pirat, Ritter). Das Spiel erinnert optisch und vom Spielgefühl an einen Mix aus Zelda und Metal Gear Solid, wobei erstere Inspiration klar dominiert. Tatsächlich entspricht der visuelle Stil dem, was ich mir seit der Veröffentlichung von Twilight Princess schon so viele Jahre für die Zelda-Reihe erhofft hatte...

Die Quests bestehen derzeit zwar hauptsächlich aus Sammeln von und dem Liefern der Gegenstände an NPCs, dennoch haben sie mir sehr viel Spaß bereitet. Vielleicht liegt es aber auch daran, dass es für die knappe Zeit am Feierabend auch einfach nur eine gute Beschäftigungstherapie war ;) Dafür entschädigt jedoch das fein ausgearbeitete Szenario, denn der Entwickler hat rund um Tilo auch seiner Welt, deren Charakteren und Gegenständen eine Bedeutung gegeben. Im spielinternen Journal kannst du interessante, belanglose oder auch einfach nur amüsante Beschreibungstexte zu Gegenständen, Charakteren und Lokationen nachlesen, während sich parallel dazu nach und nach die Geschichte entfaltet.

Da stört es weniger, das du häufiger mal über den ein oder anderen Bug stolpern wirst, in der von mir gespielten Version v1.49 gab es sogar einen Showstopper in Form eines Glitch. Da es sich hierbei um einen Early Access-Titel handelt, liegt das aber freilich in der Natur der Sache. Der Entwickler ist zudem sehr kommunikationsfreudig und reagiert schnell. In der aktuellen v1.93 sind die meisten Fehler bereits behoben und neue Features fanden ihren Weg ins Spiel.

24664992.review:
*You could neglect this review if you're in for an adventure game, rather than looking for a challenge of any sort. To me personally games aren't enjoyable if I don't need to think before advancing.*

This game is very, very hard to judge and regardless of my ultimate opinion I like most of what it offers. It's made by a really small team and it honestly is very impressive for what it is thus far. The game looks pretty decent/good, has superior animations, runs better than mediocre and plays well(despite essentially forcing a controller on you as it's clumsy without).

The setting is absolutely fantastic, the characters likeable. The concept superb. The game has a very "cozy" feeling to it as the environment is kind of cramped - with positive connotation. The writing, as far as I've seen thus far, is well done.

Now the reasons I do not recommend this game: I completed all there's to it in a little over 2 hours(steam went down for maintenance neglecting roughly a hour of playtime) and the developers stated that this would approximately be one fourth of the final product. I would be sorely disappointed if so, for it just isn't much. It's really very little(unironically, seeing you play as a rodent, for that matter) and the roadmap, judging by the previous statement, isn't impressive either. That leaves us at my biggest concern:

The stealth aspect is very poor. It's very, very superficial and very, very uninteresting. About EVERYTHING BUT the stealth is compelling, which is sour as it's the main selling point of the game. The AI is mind bogglingly stupid and can be cheesed(pun intended) simply by running. All guards are significantly slower than you are, and due to their slow and clumsy attack animations are incredibly easy to avoid. You can essentially rush past almost every single guard in the game(with the exception of a few in the very beginning) which results in them grouping up and proneblocking their way to a doorway where they'll all get stuck by humping into one another. It's a pathetic sight, and perhaps even more sad that it's easily the most efficient way to win the game. Furthermore guard are stupidly unaware and their "alarmed" mode is no more than walking to the place you created noise. Without looking around, just plain looking at the source of the noise. This means if you stand DIRECTLY next to them they won't see you. Guard don't react to ANYTHING in the environment other than noise; leaving doors open, or hauling stuff they're all apathic towards.

Lastly the sound design is generally poor, the music is decent but alot of actions lack "sound" still. That's understandable seeing it's still in development though.

Overall it's good, but the main selling point is very poorly executed. So it really boils down to what you're looking for: story and "adventuring"? This game might be for you. Any form of challenge or use of wits? Best to stay away.

24663238.review:
First and foremost, the visuals are absolutely stunning in this game - some of the most beautiful artistry I've ever seen in the medium.  The game is worth it for that reason alone, and that's a very rare thing for me to say - I tend to discount fancy graphics in general, but all I can say is, this is different.  It's more than just flash and gee-whiz, it's a fully realized artistic vision.

The writing is also great.  Whimsical and funny, it matches the visual style perfectly.

As for the gameplay, well - it's not exactly my cup of tea.  No combat, more "fetch" quests than I care for, and a lot of retreading the same ground.  Some of the puzzle platformy bits left me wrestling with the interface, which kills the fun for me.  This may be a matter of taste, but I get zero enjoyment and nothing but fustration from trying and failing over and over again to jump from one skinny rafter to another to retrieve the 6th of 7 identical items for yet another fetch quest.

The story and characters are great, however, and have kept me playing despite the shortcomings in gameplay, and the one saving grace of all the fetch quests is they require you to explore every nook and cranny of the truly beautiful environment.

A really impressive effort from a one-man studio, and I look forward to the next.

24659657.review:
I don't normally write reviews, but this game... well, let me just say that It has been a long time since I have played a game that I have enjoyed so thoroughly, not only did this game remind me of games I played in my childhood such as The Hobbit by Sierra & The legend of Zelda, but books as well like Redwall & a lot of Tolkien's work. Nostalgia is definitely one of the reasons I love it so much, but that aside, the gameplay is fantastic and the graphics/art-style is flawless.

Now, the game has its fair share of flaws that I expect to see gone on the final release, for starters, the stealth mechanic is very exploitable in its current state, and by that I mean you can literally just run past all the guards and hide in pretty much plain sight as the guard just wanders back to his post. I would definitely love to see all that patched up, and the difficulty either in different levels or just more of a challenge overall.
 
In addition to that, the game could do with some more music, I found myself playing all sorts of musical playlists to liven up the silence a little when wandering around the fantastic level design. It would also be nice to see a better graphics settings menu, as the current one is very basic and lacking in options.

It took me roughly 5 hours to complete all that this early version of the game has to offer, which is not that bad considering it’s only a small portion of what the game will be on release, I am craving more already though.

And let me just say, if you were on the fence on whether or not to get it, I would highly recommend you pick it up and support these amazing people creating it as they have such a fantastic idea as to what makes a great game, and I imagine it will cost more on the final release.

Thank you developers for creating such a fun experience, and thank you backers that raised the initial funds for the game on Indiegogo. I’m extremely excited to see what this game becomes and I will be coming back regularly to see what they add/change.

I’m not going to rate it out of 10, I don’t think that’s necessary as the game will not be out until sometime in 2017 if all goes well, but I will say that if the full release is an expanded version of what we have here? Then it will most certainly be one of my favourite games to date.

24647921.review:
できるだけネタばらさずにこのゲームの魅力的なところお話ししたいと思います！

まず、このゲームは多くのゲームと違って、自分は人間ではなく、Tiloっていうネズミの詩人です。ゲームの始まりに、Tiloは刑務所の独房にいて、そこから脱出する必要があります。
このゲームのジャンルは、アドベンチャー、RPG、ステルスです。

アドベンチャー : どうしてこの命にあったか知りに行きながら、動物の世界の社会や階層など分かるようになる上に、面白いキャラクターにも会えるでしょう。

RPG : Tiloっていうネズミになり、いろんなツール、アーマー、武器、回復アイテムを拾って、使ったり装備したりします。やればやるほど、Tiloのいろんなところは強くなれます。

ステルス : ゆっくりしゃがみながら動ける上に、強い敵にばれてしまった場合、
クローゼットやチェストに入って、隠れます。あと、いろんな落ちているものを投げて、敵に特定なところに動いてもらえます。（The Last of Usみたいに)

これを開発しているのはある一人だけなので、いつか日本語版が出るか分かりませんが、出たらいいですね。

いつものことですが、私はアメリカ人なので、日本語の間違っているところがあるかもしれません。申し訳ありません。

先ほど、Youtubeに動画をアップさせていただきましたので、よろしければ、ご覧になってください。日本語字幕は付いています。

https://youtu.be/G9ugmOhoXu0

24642486.review:
Купил сразу и не пожалел. Интересная и необычная по концепции игра. Надеюсь, разработчики доведут её до релиза.

Плюсы:
+ красочная графика, обильное освещение.
+ оптимизация. Работает довольно-таки шустро на средней машинке.
+ сложность. В игре нужна внимательность, расчетливость и хорошая память.
+ наличие квестов и инвентаря с предметами. Это делает игру разнообразной.
+ наличие довольно-таки богатого ЛОРа по игре.
+ секретные ходы, ачивки.
+ атмосферность.
+ музыка. Приятная слуху музыка. Не зря в главной роли менестрель. :)
+ сеты одежды. Можно собирать разные сеты брони, которые дают разные эффекты и по-разному влияют на отношение окружающих к вам.

Минусы:
- баги. Да, всё верно. Не стоит ожидать от игры в ЕА отсутствие багов. Один раз стражник крыс после погони за мной застрял на лестнице и если его "разозлить", то он не мог двигаться. Из-за этого от него было нельзя спрятаться и сохраниться. Вылечилось переходом в другую локацию - тогда позиции стражников сбросились. Кроме того бывают баги с анимацией и т.п. 
- на данный момент разработано только 25% сюжета.


9 из 10.

Amazingly beautiful and well animated, this game feels like Redwall brought to life.  As a small, adorable mouse, you don't have any fighting skills to speak of.  Sneak around, hide in the chests, and try to escape the prison.  Start your quest to find your wife and child in a prison full of intimidating, growling rats.

Right now, the developers need additional funding for the game, so they've released it in early access.  I haven't completed the content that's currently available, but the main mechanics seem solidly implemented, and the environments are a joy to navigate.  Tilo is so well animated, I just love watching him warily sniff and twitch as he's hiding from guards behind a pillar.

24638672.review:
I was playing version 1.49 early access. So that is what the review is on.
First note the game is not complete (you will stop before the story is over) it is still in early access so keep that in mind when you are considering this game.
Second note as a warning: [spoiler] There is mention of a child's passing which may be difficult to some gamers.	[/spoiler]

When I saw this game the first thing that popped into my mind was Redwall and it does seem that it share a similar world with animals with human elements.  The world and events are filled in through finding hidden items like the roses and reading the footnotes in conversations giving this world a lot of depth without all the narration. Right now there isn't any voice acting besides sound effects.
Your goal is to find your loved one and free yourself to do such you need to sneak, hide, and disguise yourself to achieve your objectives. The game has a sneak meter showing you how alert the enemies are to your location you can often reset the meter by hiding in a barrel/ chest/ cupboard. Guards are not too bright but can see pretty well in the dark. I ran into some issues with some guard stuck in location instead of patrolling or they would chase me and then get stuck in doorways. At the moment there isn't any combat, some guards you can throw objects like bottle on their head and knock them out temporarily. Not thing stays locked out or unconscienced for long.  There are food items just about everywhere for healing which your health is more tied to item sets than anything else. Its wroth the time to find the different outfits as charters interact with you differently. Where it is at the moment the game is really pretty with a lot of potential and stops mid story.

24608430.review:
A gripping tale that's focused on your adventures as the mouse Tilo in a world that is bigger than you in almost every way. The dialogue and scattered documents often have footnotes that help flesh out the world and introduce some much loved flavor text, and the stealth mechanics don't feel overly convoluted or obtuse. There are the occasional moments where you'll pop into your inventory, unaware that you've stopped in line of sight of a rat who comes thumping after you, forcing you to flee on all fours and duck under the table or cupboard in the next room.

As I've stated the world really does feel alive and care has been taken to flesh out the lore down to the smallest details. Everything from the last king's cowardly retreat at his last battle, to melting down large coins with his face on them (Cowards) to make the more modern Florin coins, contributes to the game's excellent worldbuilding. Narrative focus rings strongly with this game, and I think it has myself and many others wanting to sneak our way to more mystery and intrigue.

24607756.review: this game has a cute mouse and scary rats and you can play as the cute mouse

24604682.review: I've barely played this game and it's not yet finished being made, so take this review with a grain of salt.  It will be updated twice, once when I've beaten it (If I can in it's current state) and again when the full game's inevitably released.  I say inevitably because despite it's weaknesses it may very well end up the next big hit on the market, as despite it's indie nature of unpolish the native creativity with gameplay and decent story make this game a good look's worth by itself.  I say that, but it's not the main, generic story that catches the mind, but the world story sent to you through notes, books, and dialogue, which strangely allows the player to look up keywords in a sort of dictionary to learn more about them while working through the conversation.  It's a nice touch that is great for those who enjoy story or have trouble getting into the terms of any given fictional world.  On a gameplay note, it plays like a stealth game, with a condensed version of Dark Souls life and stamina as your gauge.  You read that right, gauge.  This game gets VERY clever in it's gameplay, as your ability to sprint is DIRECTLY tied to your health bar.  The game is initially over-saturated with food to replinish it, though I've yet to determine if this remains the case, and if you don't have the chance to heal, it doesn't matter how much food you have.  A fundumentally changing aspect of the game at least in my playtrhough though is the lack of map.  You, as the player, are supposed to be able to find maps to areas, and open them with the LB button.  However, I for some reason, consistently cannot, reminding me (As little does in this game) that it IS unfinished.  There is also the unexcusable fallacy of save points in this game.  To save the game, you must be hiding in any number of the containers you can hide in within the game.  This creates the potential to not save for excessive amounts of time, and forgetting to save properly has lead to game failure in the past for many games with the same limitation.  The game SHOULD let you save if you are not in the awareness cone or radius of the enemies, I.E. safe.  Not JUST when you're hiding.  The last problem is in the weird focus of the appearance of the game, which has heavy art but little optimization, with graphical glitchs being common, such as seeing through the walls to out of bounds and your beloved hats going nuts and your clothes clipping through you like air.  None of these glitches are potent or long-lasting, but with the game looking the way it does, it's VERY immersion breaking... BUT as I said before at the start of this rant, the game's pretty good so far despite these shortcomings.  If you get it though, remember that it is a W.I.P and any or all of these problems may not be fixed.

24584435.review:
Ich habe dieses Spiel jetzt ca. 4-5 Stunden angespielt und muss sagen: Topspiel!

Ghost of a Tale macht es einem leicht sich in den putzigen Charakter, welcher zwar stumm, aber nicht ausdrucksschwach daher kommt, einzufühlen. Trotz "Early Access" ist kommt einem das Spiel, bis auf ein paar wenige Bugs, ziemlich komplett vor und bleibt durchgehend spannend und knackig.
Für den Preis von 19,99€ (Aktion -10%: 17,99€) bekommt man ein stealthlastiges Game, welches mit einem frischen atmosphärischen Setting bzw. Flair arbeitet. 

Zur Grafik: 9/10 Pkt.

Grafikeinstellungen sind bis auf Chromatische Abberation, DOF, Motionblur nicht veränderbar, was aber kein Nachteil sein muss.
Grafisch kommt man aber auch trotzdem nicht zu kurz und dies trotz meiner etwas älteren Nvidia Geforce GTX 670 (2Gb). Es sind bei mir so durchschnittlich 50-60 Fps drin (FPS-Counter über Debugmenu einstellbar).

Zur Performance: 10/10 Pkt.

Es gibt keine Ladescreens mit Ausnahme des Startbildschirms, es gibt gewisse Bereiche im Spiel wo man merkt, dass etwas nachgeladen wird! Aber nur durch einen einzigen Mikroruckler (Fps-drop) bei mir bemerkbar!

Zum Gameplay: 8/10 Pkt.

Das was zuweilen im Spiel enthalten ist ansich ganz wunderbar. Es kann sich sehen lassen. Jeder Gegenstand/Rüstungsteil (gilt als Verkleidung bei einem kompletten Set) dient seinem Zwecke und funktioniert einwandfrei. 
Bei der Steuerung möchte ich aber jedem den Tipp geben das Spiel mit einem Gamepad zu spielen da
die Keyboard/Maus -Steuerung, im Bezug auf die Mausführung nicht ganz optimal ist. Spielbar ohne große Probleme nur eben nicht optimal.

Zur Story: 10/10 Pkt.

Erlaube mir die Story einmal mit 10/10 zu bewerten, obwohl ich Ghost of a Tale noch nicht durch habe (laut Entwickler aber auch noch nicht ganz fertig), aber ich sage schon anhand von dem jetztigen Stand welchen ich sah, die Story (Auch die Lore der Spielwelt) hat mich gepackt und gefällt mir sehr! Hoffe sie bleibt im späteren Spielverlauf auch so motivierend!

Fazit: 9,25/10 Pkt.
Ein Spiel was Seinesgleichen sucht! Trotz älter bzw. genretypischer Spielmechaniken überhaupt NIE langweilig oder in die Länge ziehend und ein echtes Schnäppchen für den Preis!!!
Meine persönliche Empfehlung: Kaufen.

PS: Ich werde diese Review später untenanstehend noch zu einem Vergleich hin editieren und updaten.

24584054.review:
Je vais le dire tout de suite les accès anticipé j'étais pas super motivé mais après avoir vu les images du jeu je me suis dis pourquoi pas.

Et bien il faut avouer que ... Ouah il est super fun même non abouti.

Je suis vraiment content de mon achat de ce jeu et je suis loin d'être le seul.

Mais avant de donner en détail mon point de vue voici les fameux +/-

(Mon avis est durant l'accès anticipé cela peut donc être modifié dans la version finale)

   Les Plus:

- Le jeu est vraiment beau.

- Aussi surprenant que ça soit il consomme peu de ressources.

- On se sent faible dans le corps de cette souris et il faut ruser pour passer.

- Les "niveaux" sont cohérent  même si c'est plus une grosse map.

- Plein de raccourcis à ouvrir 

- Des quetes débloquant des passages fermés a l'allé ...

   Les Moins

- ... Ce qui entraine bien trop d'allers retours 

- L'IA qui nous oublie trop facilement (même si l'énnemi voit clairement ou on se cache il arrete les recherches et s'en va)

- A la fin on ne se cache plus mais on rush dans les aller retours.

- Les rats ne sont pas dangereux car leurs attaques mettent super longtemps à être lancées.

- ...


Bref Je suis entièrement conquis par ce jeu qui m'à montré que même si le héros n'a rien d'un barbare surarmé il peut être attachant. Les points négatifs tournent en général autour de l'IA ce qui peut se régler par la suite donc je ne me fait pas de soucis pour l'avenir de ce jeu.

Je le recommande chaudement si l'angais ne vous fait pas peur et que vous souhaitez soutenir un jeu qui risque d'être une pépite à sa sortie.

24580382.review:
Ghost of a Tale is an interesting Stealth game, involving dodging guards and solving puzzles, questing around and putting on costumes, both to fool characters and look awesome. It's also ADORABLE. The main character is a mouse jailed for sedition, in a jail full of rat guards, most of which do not have any interest in leaving you alive.

The game plays really well, for looking like something where all the focus is on the art... And I mean that in the best way possible. The art in this game is -incredible-. The character models look fantastic, the animations are beautiful, and the atmosphere and lighting are awesome. There are still some quirks to be worked out -- lighting in some areas seems a bit jumpy -- but this is part of the Early Access process.

The gameplay is fairly classic and intuitive for a Stealth style game. Don't get in combat unless it's absolutely forced, because as a tiny mouse in a jail full of armored rat guards, your ability to defend yourself ranks among the same levels as a loaf of damp bread. Instead, you'll spend your time watching patterns, dashing from hiding place to hiding place, and outwitting the guards at every turn as you jump from one place to the next.

Sounds are a bit sparse right now, but the game doesn't need a ton of them. The pitter patter of your own feet, the heavy clanking of guards moving around, and the musical strikes when you are spotted and running for your life are effective. Character dialog would be interesting to see vocalized, but I can imagine finding a good voice actor to play a male mouse would be a trick at best.

There are still issues, certainly, but it's a matter of ironing out kinks, definitely a process. There is still some bugfixing to be done, options to tweak and tailor (for example, at the time of writing this, PS4/Dualshock controllers are not supported, but Xbox controllers are), and other little issues. I felt a little overwhelmed with quests at one point, where I had so many active at once, and picking through to determine which ones are active and how to complete certain objectives was daunting. But none of these have taken away from the main gaming experience, which is the most important matter.

Ghost of a Tale is an excellent game already, and by the time it's fully finished, it is absolutely worth checking out. Just remember that old mouse proverb...

"Save early, save often!"

You'll need it.

24578342.review:
Link to the full video review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kzN4jF4wAyg

[b][i]"the NPC interaction here isn’t just simply there to force feed you context to the gameplay, but to be there in addition. These aren’t just two pillars of game design leaning on each other to hold up a price tag; this is the evidence of a lot of love and hard work going into both the game’s world and how you play within it."[/i][/b]

I wanna preface this one with a little disclaimer - I was very kindly sent an early access/beta key for this game for the purpose of testing and of review. My opinion is 100% unaltered and honest, drawn entirely from the experiences I have had with the game. 

[b]Graphics[/b]
All in all, this game manages to pull off what I feel a lot of AAA games simply cannot, with their intense scope and budget - utilizing almost every aspect of its appearance in a way that actually counts, whether just for simply building atmosphere or truly blending the realms of graphics and gameplay. Turning a corner, unsure if you’re going to find an enemy, only to spot the light reflecting off the cold red eyes of a rat is an amazing feat of design. Sure I could just walk around and find out, or hide and listen out for footsteps or snoring, but that’s also where this game shines out. Time and time again, you see or hear stories of early access games doing the bare minimum or not even that! - there’s one path, with only one way to get on it and that’s your game - gg wp £15, here’s 0 updates.

All in all, at a time where the low budgets of indie games crush the game under stylised graphics, we see a game that not only manages to achieve a unique style for itself, but one that also refuses to sacrifice that fairly gritty sense of realism that it sets out to deliver. An absolute 10/10 from me, in this regard.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
 very minimal focus on combat puts you into a position in which you have to take care. Being sure of where you’re throwing an item to distract an enemy or working out which hiding spots you can run to as  you make your way down a hall all highlight the strongest virtue of them all - patience. Learning walk cycles, figuring out blind spots and altogether using your environment, transforming what was a dark hand around your neck as a tool, and turning it around against those out to catch you.
The puzzles in the game present themselves very well - a guard standing in front of a door that’s locked, and only he has the key. What do you do? Well, you can make some noise and draw him out, sneaking up and stealing it as he walks back to his post. Or how about throwing a glass of grease, which he’ll then slip on as he comes to investigate? Or what if you snuck past him, up the stairs and knocked him unconscious by pushing down a barrel.
I think this - the options - are one of the cooler parts of the gameplay in Ghost of a Tale. There are definitely a lot in which there’s one clear way, but the open-ended aspect of this game almost give each hall you walk down a sandbox-y vibe, and it’s great.

[b]Story[/b]
Now, I’m a huge fan of story in games - where people hate the idea of cinematicism and 3 hour long movie-games, I do enjoy them. I’ve been an avid reader all my life, and there’s nothing I love more than to jump into a world and learn everything about it. However, given the nature of this game and the sense of urgency and suspense it often puts on you, I feel that this stripped back approach was the best way to deliver it. Not only can sneaking into a guarded room feel scary as hell, it’s also rewarding as fuck to find a prize that will then enrich your experience and understanding of the setting, instead of just finding another damn pile of coins like most other games would do.

This style of delivery is fantastic and while it might not be my personal favourite for every game, it was the best choice of delivery for [i]this[/i] game.

It was the level of detail that really sunk it all in - a lot of the NPC interaction here isn’t just simply there to force feed you context to the gameplay, but to be there in addition. These aren’t just two pillars of game design leaning on each other to hold up a price tag; this is the evidence of a lot of love and hard work going into both the game’s world and how you play within it.

These system of storytelling fits the design and gameplay of the game perfectly. The option to focus more on the thrill and excitement of gameplay is never abandoned, but the depth and intrigue of the world is also always there, should you choose to look for it and I think no matter what you prefer - intense and detailed stories or a heavy focus on that clever puzzle based gameplay, you’ll have a good time with Ghost of a Tale.

The game also features a questing system, with optional dialogue alongside them and no steps have been skipped here. For example, I actually got annoyed at myself. I’d just hunted back through the jail to find a hidden stash for these two mice in a cell up on the surface. I’d managed to retrieve it and get back to them, but the day cycle was shifting and one of them was already asleep. In talking to the other, I had the option to hand in the quest, but I ended up exploring the dialogue options and performed him a song (or two) to help him fall asleep. This played a nice animation of the lyrics appearing, as the lute backing track played and after which, the mouse had fallen asleep. There I was, with the clock nearing midnight with a quest I had to hand in in the day time. 

It was the level of detail that really sunk it all in - a lot of the NPC interaction here isn’t just simply there to force feed you context to the gameplay, but to be there in addition. These aren’t just two pillars of game design leaning on each other to hold up a price tag; this is the evidence of a lot of love and hard work going into both the game’s world and how you play within it.


[b]Overview[/b]
Overall, I can’t believe how positive this has come out. A few words to remember: I have only played this game for a few hours and while this “early access” opens a lot up to you as a player, it’s worth remembering that only about 25%-a third of the game is currently playable, as it goes further into development. Despite this, is this game worth picking up? Yes. Outside of the very few and acceptable bugs I’ve seen - considering this is early access - I honestly don’t have many complaints at all. 

If this sounds good to, I urge you to pick it up. If even just the graphics or setting tickle your fancy, I would also recommend it. A stellar entry to the gaming industry and one that definitely raises the bar for all early access games coming in the future.

24574355.review:
Ghost of a Tale is a stealth/action/adventure about Tilo the minstral mouse, imprisoned for sedition, and trying to escape and find his family.

The game itself is mainly focused on exploration, with Tilo not actually being able to engage in combat (with the exception of a well aimed bottle to the head), and it works well. Combat would have removed a lot of the charm from the game, and it exudes charm by the bucket load.

NPCs are well written and often funny, reminding me at times of the original Monkey Island games. Characters are fantastically modelled and animated - not a suprise given that the main developer is an animation guy who spent years working at Dreamworks and Universal Studios.

I'm not entirely sure I've ever recommended an early access title before, but this one really deserves your attention. I'm actually surprised at the price point this has been released at - double the price (once the game is finished) would be worth the price of entry.

There are bugs and issues as with any game that is still in production, but the devs are open for feedback and will often ask for save games/logs to see what has gone wrong.

I've totally fallen for Ghost of a Tale. It's rapidly turning into on of those rare games that reminds you why you're a gamer in the first place. Give it a go.

Je crois n'avoir jamais joué à un jeu "indé" aussi "professionnel". La variété des environnements, le soin apporté aux éclairges, l'intuitivité du gameplay, la richesse dans la simplicité... Tout, dans Ghost of a Tale, semble être le fruit d'un studio pro et pourtant... Le Character design et le level design sont riches et détaillés, classiques mais savoureux. Le Gameplay plaira aux amateurs d'inflitration et d'exploration. On entre très vite dans le jeu, quelques minutes suffisent à s'approprier les capacités du personnage et partir à l'aventure (parfait si comme moi vous n'avez plus trop le temps de consacrer 3 ou 4 heures par jour à un RPG). Le monde Médiéval-Fantastique de Tilo (le héros) est à la fois familier et original, peuplé d'animaux si expressifs qu'ils en deviennent étrangement humains.
C'est un peu comme si Walt Disney avait sorti son "Thief : Dark Project".
Il reste encore quelques petits bugs, on attend la trad française... Mais sinon c'est un sans faute.

J'ai hâte de voir ce que SeithCG nous reserve pour un avenir proche et lointain, vraiment.

I played version 1.49 of the Early Access game.

I personally love this game. The main character is an adorable little mouse, but it's a sinister world where you have to hide and evade armor-clad rats.

The dialogue is witty, and are really in character. There's bits of lore to discover about the world that also really makes the place immersive. The animations are absolutely subperb (the main dev has animated in films like The Prince of Egypt, The Road to Eldorado, Flushed-Away, Despicable Me, and The Lorax). The environments are very well designed and are a treat for me to look at.

Unfortunately as it's Early Access, it's not quite all there, but I still really enjoyed my time playing this and don't regret the purchase.
Currently, in its Early Access state there are some minor and major bugs (no crashes or save corruption, but some bugs seemed to prevent quest progression, quitting and reloading the game seemed to fix this though, and I imagine the big bugs will be fixed soon).
Some sounds also seem to be absent, and some GUI seems plain (basically just the main menu).

Overall though, this is a great game.

24564349.review:
So far, I have spent a little over 5 hours in the game, taking it slow, trying to take in all the amazing details. 

Like the smoke from the torches, not just clipping through the cave ceiling but actually venting along the curved rock. The gentle rocking of the ivy, the bending of gras as you pass through it. The way Tilo's (and the rats) extremeties are flooded with sunlight when they are between the camera and the sun. It makes them look so soft and also small and alive. It is such a clever use of visuals! The smooth, transitionless and always perfectly in character movement of Tilo as you speed up and slow down. Controlling Tilo and seeing his animations almost makes me feel like I am a mouse (not just the shadow of a mouse ;)). They are both true to life and anthropomorphized. They are just perfect! 

The dialogue (written text, there won't be voice overs in the foreseeable future) is witty and engaging. The dialogue options you get to choose from seem very varied, although I haven't tested different routes. It is remarkable though for a game of such small scope that characters will react to the way you are clothed sometimes. One guy for example notices if you wear the thiefs mask and addresses this during your conversation. The game is very "efficient" with its lore. You won't find volume after volume of walls of text like in the Witcher games or TES, but what you get to read is bursting with character, vividness and charm that totally makes up for a seeming lack of content.

The music deserves a special mention too! The theme track is brilliant in the way it is complex yet feels all of a piece and hopeful and moody. I love it! The music nicely supports gamemechanics (raised alarms) or sets the right mood for conversations. All in all it mingles perfectly with the games visual art and thematic setting and still is enjoyable just by itself.

This game does so many things I haven't seen in any AAA production it is just incredible! And, so far, it all comes together to make a good and engaging game as well! Great job and keep up the good work!

24563542.review:
[h1]Intro[/h1]
So, an early access title. Had my share of bad experiences, but reading up on this little indie title made me feel like these guys deserve the support.

Now, 7 hours into the game and I've just finished the early access part. Didn't 100% it, but I did explore and mess around with the game quite a bit. They say this is roughly 25 to 30% of the game, so I'm expecting the final version to be roughly 15 to 30 hours long, depending on how much of a completionist you are. Speedrunners will probably manage to finish this game within 5 or 10, considering the current stealth mechanics.

[h1]My opinion and experience[/h1]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ImwB2fNGtsI
This brings me to my main concern about this game. The stealth mechanics aren't really all there, it seems. The game feels a lot like Styx: Master of Shadows, and I really loved that game. I enjoy Ghosting missions in Far Cry, Metal Gear Solid, Assassin's Creed, Payday 2 and pretty much all games that let me. I want to be the silent assassin, or thief, that nobody noticed until they went looking for that item that I already extracted. So, this game is kind of an oddball. It says 'action RPG' in the store, but this Early Access part was void of any real action (combat) and RPG elements. The RPG could be the costumes, but then again, these costumes are required for certain events, so they're not really RPG, they're more like story mechanics. They are fun though, I like the Ranger outfit a lot, but as far as RPG goes, there's nothing really there so far.
So, I'd say this game is a story-driven stealth-based adventure game. But again, the stealth mechanics aren't quite there. The guards spot you, they chase you, you run around a corner, hide and they'll just stand there: "Er, what?" Combine this with the guard outfit, and you don't even have to wait for them to go away. You hide, open inventory, switch outfits with a button press and you can just exit and they won't even question your pressence. I do like the humour in this specific situation, but as far as stealth-based gameplay, this isn't all that great.

Aside from the lack of stealth-specific gameplay elements, this game actually has quite a lot going for it though. The graphics are gorgeous. The environment is very detailed. The sound effects and music are spot on. The story telling isn't bad and the dialogue options are fun, although I didn't get the feeling different options had different outcomes (which I think are required when giving the player the option to pick a response).
Another enjoyable aspect is the fact that you get objectives and sometimes mild hints to where to find said objective, but it's not all that concrete. I would appreciate some hints to be a little vaguer, or even hidden behind certain dialogue choices (pick wrong, don't get a hint, no do-overs), but there is definitely quite a bit for the player to find out for themselves.

And of course, there are still a bunch of annoyances caused by bugs as well. Sometimes the mouse has trouble raising his foot high enough. Sometimes the camera gets sorta stuck - when going too fast down a small hole. And sometimes you lose progress because an enemy gets stuck in 'agro' and you can't save during combat, meaning you have to reload and retrace your step. Some optimization issues as well, where the framerate tanks to <15 when just walking around a corner (because it's loading another area). 
And then there are the major bugs that I haven't experienced myself, but that people have been talking about on the forums. Not all controllers work well. There are inconsistencies between reboots, as in: restart the game, and both the environment and enemies might behave slightly differently.
But all that is easily forgiven, considering this is Early Access. These issues all need to be resolved before release though, obviously.

[h1]Summary and verdict[/h1]
We'll do a nice little pros(+) and cons(-) list then:
+ Graphically amazing
+ Detailed environments
+ Story telling and deep lore for fans
+ Sound and music is perfect (movie quality)

- Stealth-gameplay needs a major upgrade
- No action or RPG in this Early Access (could be in the rest of the game, but don't count on it for now)
- Some controls (especially when it comes to platforming) are annoying (mouse just slides off of a square wooden beam)
- Minor and major bugs (it is E.A. after all)

So, do I recommend this game? Well, I do, but only for this simple reason: this very small team are doing something that hasn't been overdone yet. The stealth-genre can do with some good new titles. The story-driven genre, especially in the indie world, are usually lacking gameplay. So yeah, this title might actually up the ante for indie developers.

If you want to see this product succeed, back the developers. If you're on the fence, then please, just put it on your wishlist and keep an eye out for it.

24559054.review:
So happy to say 'This game is even better than expected'

After watching this game since I spotted it on Indiegogo a while ago and supported it ..Word got around and I was so pleased when reached it funding goals...
And Now that its early access!!..I cant believe how good this little gem is!!...

IMHO It plays better than many AAA+ Stealth Genre Games on the market today..

Surpassed all my expectations..

It has only a few tiny bugs that Ive noticed and these in no way affect the overall gameplay..
I've only had to load a save game once so far..when I encountered a game breaking bug but this is to be expected in Early access and was by no means a hassle...

The level Design is perfect for the Tone and mood of the Game...Tight labyrythian pathways which open out into larger explarable areas..all seamlessly transitioned...
Night and day cycle adds to the atmosphere and having to use a lantern in areas is a great touch ...unlike so many games that try to get it right and fail..this game just seems to work ..

The enemy ai is simple but it suits the game design..and makes Stealth fun and engaging...loads of secret areas and loot I was totally surprised at how immersive this game is..it really pulls you in...
Otherwise a very solid effort..The Sole Developer "Seith" should be commended for such a brilliant and no doubt herculean task...

The Character Design and enemies are perfectly designed and really suit the atmosphere and tone...Enemies are fairly predictable so most encounters involve a glorious puzzle like minigame of timing, hiding, sneaking, or running away if your plan all goes to hell. In most cases even if you are spotted by guards you can usually escape backtracking or evading long enough to try again when the guards lose sight of you...

The menu design and inventory is simple..uncluttered and works perfectly ..although I did encounter an occasional gliche on the map gui..I'm certain this and other minor bugs can be easily patched out..
having only played a few hours so far and suddenly becoming aware of how much this game has to offer so far..I am really looking forward to finding every secret and completing every objective...The main character is quite cute and his animations are smooth..fluid and rarely glichy...

Controls are intuitive (I've only used Keyboard and mouse so far but they respond perfectly but I did need to invert the mouse vertical axis  ...a personal preference)
The Character moves about the world with style and grace for the most part and transitioning from a full run to hiding in a chest or under a table is a simple straighforward action for the most part ...

Music and sound effects are atmospheric and emotional...The music that plays if you are spotted isnt annoying by any means and heightens the tension ...You can usually hear guards on patrol quite easily which helps with sneaking about...


Overall gameplay is engaging,,,even if you are slightly bored by modern Stealth games...This one has a uniqueness all of its own and a testament to quality Indie Developement ...

Huge thumbs up...if you like stealth games...I am sure you will find something really special and magical about this game....well done all round excellent title that I'm sure will become a classic as time goes by....Top effort and its basically made entirely by one guy!!!

Easily scores 9/10

24552948.review:
[quote=Кейт ДиКамилло. «Приключения мышонка Десперо»]...непростая судьба уготована всякому мышонку и человеку, который смеет быть не таким, как все.[/quote]

Впервые проект [b]Ghost of a Tale[/b] появился на горизонте в начале 2013 году на [b]IndieGoGo[/b], где автор-одиночка просил за свою игру чуть менее пятидесяти тысяч евро. По меркам современной игроиндустрии это не слишком большая сумма, да и разработчик не позиционировал свой проект как игру ААА-уровня.

Главным героем игры является мышонок по имени Тило, который вместе с супругой Мерра выступает в качестве менестреля по всему сказочному королевству, населенному животными. На одном из выступлений, героя арестовывают, а жену уводят в неизвестном направлении. Очнувшись в темнице, Тило находит под тарелкой с едой записку от неизвестного и ключ от камеры. Так начинаются приключения нашего героя. В сюжете множество прорех как о месте событий, так и самой завязке, но в [b]Ghost of a Tale[/b] можно найти множество различных записок и журналов, которые восполнят пробелы в истории и расскажут более подробно о самом королевстве, а также о некоторых его обитателях. Например, найдя комнату главного надзирателя тюрьмы, мы узнаем о злодеяниях других преступников, в том числе и жабы-пирата, нашего первого знакомого, облюбовавшего камеру напротив. Есть в игре и сюжетный квест, посвященный предыстории и жизни Тило и его супруги, для этого надо собирать разбросанные по локациям красные розы.

Сразу хочется отметить сказочный антураж [b]Ghost of a Tale[/b] и внимательность к мелким деталям, на окнах висит паутина, по темнице бегают разноцветные жучки, повсюду слышатся различные шорохи, а звуки лютни очень удачно подчеркивают атмосферу происходящего. И не удивительно, ведь под ником [b]Seith[/b] скрывается известный французский аниматор [b]Lionel Gallat[/b], проработавший в киноиндустрии более 15 лет в компаниях [b]Dreamworks[/b] и [b]Universal Studios[/b], и приложивший руку к таким проектам, как [i]«Принц Египта», «Подводная братва», «Гадкий я», «Лоракс»[/i] и многим другим.

Хочется с положительной стороны отметить дизайн уровней, а также множество скрытых лазеек и ходов. При внимательном изучении локаций можно найти тайные тропы, упрощающие передвижение между темницей и катакомбами или замковым двором, это помогает не только быстро передвигаться, значительно сокращая путь, но и избегать ненужных встреч с многочисленной охраной.

Геймплей представляет из себя стелс-экшен с решением несложных ситуативных головоломок и легким вкраплением RPG-элементов. Тило значительно уступает врагам в мощи, и поэтому единственным способом для него избежать неприятности, является возможность красться и прятаться. Некоторых охранников можно оглушить на время, используя объекты окружения, но не все будут агрессивно настроены к главному герою, так, например, крыса-кузнец за умеренную плату готова помочь советом, а заключенные за выполнение небольших поручений готовы поделиться полезными предметами.
Некоторые задания можно выполнить только в ночное время суток и наоборот, да и мир игры изменяется в зависимости от расположения солнца на небосводе. Следует отметить и наряды героя, которые не только преображают его внешне, но и меняют отношение к себе у NPC.

На данной версии игры (1.49) еще достаточно много недоработок. Больше всего смущает AI врагов, которые бывают не видят героя в упор, то упираются в невидимые препятствия, то не реагируют на попытку спрятаться. Есть проблемы с оптимизацией и звуком, который иногда пропадает. Обязательно нужна озвучка, которой очень не хватает во многих моментах.

В целом [b]Ghost of a Tale[/b] вызывает положительные эмоции благодаря отличной сказочной атмосфере, грамотным дизайном уровней, качественной физикой, харизматичному герою и множествам секретов. На первый взгляд, игра может показаться непродолжительной, имея всего пять NPC и чуть более двух десятков квестов, но поверьте это впечатление обманчиво. Хочется пожелать автору только удачи и успехов, ведь [b]Ghost of a Tale[/b] действительно может получиться сказочно хорошей, как в прямом, так и в переносном смысле этого слова!

[b]P.S.[/b] Обзор написан одним из авторов [b]Special Games Club[/b]. С другими обзорами нашей группы вы можете ознакомиться [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/SpecialGamesClub#curation][u]здесь[/u][/url].

24552914.review:
So far, I'm totally stoked for this game.
It looks damn cute!
The overall graphics are looking really good, especially considering that this game is being developed by only a handful of people. Apparently the Dev often has been asked if the screenshots have been photoshopped :D
Seriously, it looks great.

The gameplay relies on Stealth and Exploration. You also have an inventory and can find lots of "tools" to help you get through unharmed (e.g. bottles to temporarily knock out guards, Lanterns, Sticks for creating distractions and helping you getting past certain areas, food to replenish health and stamina and more!)
There even are some nicely hidden secrets to be found (revealing collectibles)
Also there is different clothing to be found. Its purpose: Looking cute and boosting your stats (stamina, health, etc.)
And if you're into lore, you'll be pleased to know that there are many books and notices to be found.

Keep in mind that this early access title includes roughly 25-30% of the final game (offering some hours of gameplay)

Addendum:
I bought this game 3 times: For my girlfriend, my brother and for myself.
Follow my example and help the Devs completing developement of this game :)

The writing is great. I found the NPC dialogue funny and charming (and I am a broken shell of a man).
It's mostly exploring and stealth. I assume there's combat but I haven't seen any yet (update: fairly sure there isn't any).
It doesn't hold your hand in regards to placing markers and checkpoints everywhere, you have to look around.

et contra:
Definitely requires a controller.
Not much of a challenge so far, as there's healing items all over the place.
If stealth could be tweaked so you don't have to move at a snail's pace even when enemies have their backs turned then that would be good.
Inventory screen is a bit of a mess. 
The usual bugs in an early release.


I recommend this game if you like stealth, exploration and adorable rodents.

24549413.review:
Начну сразу с пары минусов, так как они изрядно доставали во время прохождения. Если их пофиксить, то игра будет великолепна.

1.  Авто-сохранения есть только после разговоров с NPC.  Так только ручное сохранение, причём надо обязательно найти безопасное место, иначе игра не даст сохраниться. В первый раз из-за этого я потерял минут 40 геймплея. Пришлось снова обыскивать все комнаты, собирать все предметы и т.п. В игре, где собирательство предметов занмиает важную роль, на мой взгляд, стоит почаще авто-сохраняться. Например, после каждого найденного квестового предмета. Или лучше вообще не отбирать все найденные предметы после смерти, а просто возрождать героя в постели.

2. Стражников слишком много, чуть ли не на каждом углу. Видят они хорошо. Из-за этого игра шустро выродилась из исследования и стелза в бесконечные побегушки от врагов. Понравилось, как рядом с одним стражником открывается норка, благодаря которой можно его легко обойти. Было бы здорово, если бы с другими стражниками было так же. То есть была бы система норок, через которую можно безопасно попасть в любую часть замка.

Есть ещё технические проблемы (ИИ застревает, не спадает тревога, проседания fps при подзагрузке уровня, застревание в текстуре, вылет), но на геймплей это сильно не влияет + для раннего доступа игра очень и очень хорошо выглядит.

В целом игра очень понравилась. На редкость харизматичный персонаж, маленький мышонок в разных одёжках и с лютней за спиной. Забавные квестовые персонажи. Красивая тщательно проработання локация. Интересная атмосфера. Понравилось, что у мышонка есть три разных способа осветить помещение. Часто ходил со свечкой просто потому, что со стороны это выглядит очень здорово, хотя свечка и освещает хуже всего. Реакция персонажей на костюмы главного героя тоже часто радовала. В общем, надеюсь, что у авторов всё получится, и в итоге мы все увидим очень качественную и интересную адвенчуру.

这是一个非常棒的游戏！
在他推出体验版之前，让我持续关注这款游戏的动力无疑是在看过演示和配图之后，画面题材的表现颇具迪士尼，梦工厂的影子[其实名字也蛮相像的不是吗]，这样所体现的精致让我眼前一亮，现在上手之后，确实是这样！

在我了解到开发者的团队规模非常小的时候[大部分他还是独立完成]，我已经对游戏有所体验，很难想象这样的’‘精致’‘需要他花费什么来完成，在看到开发者的品味和态度来讲，我已经对游戏有了更大的期望。

对于游戏初期的体验版本有些许不满，同样的BUG在不少地方出现，但我相信问题在后面都会得到修复。

那么中世纪加上老鼠的童话，值得一试！

Je n'aurais jamais cru m'attacher autant à un jeu du genre. Je suis le genre de joueur qui ne finit pas un jeu, même Skyrim ou fallout 4, car je me lasse trop facilement. Rare sont les jeux qui me donnent le besoin de le redémarrer dès que je clique sur "quit game".

+++
-Les graphiques sont superbes, à l'égal de bien des titres AAA. Je n'ai rien à redire
-L'histoire est captivante: chaque page se doit d'être lue pour bien comprendre une belle histoire et une originale toile de fond
-Le gameplay est simple est fluide. Les quêtes sont simples à comprendre et, parfois, simple à résoudre. Soyez pro-actifs et amassez tout sur votre chemin!

---
-Bugs et glitches, très mineurs. C'est un early access, après tout!
-Quelques animations peuvent être améliorées, comme grimper une échelle
-Au bout de quelques temps, On se rend compte que de courir du point A en alertant tout le monde et rapidement se cacher au point B est plus rapide que de la jouer espion. Ça brise un peu l'effet du jeu, je suggère une augmentation du niveau de l'IA afin que d'attirer l'attention soit un réel risque à prendre.

Conclusion: J'aimerais tant que tous les accès anticipés aient ce niveau de qualité. De grands espoirs pour ce jeu qui rappelle Redwall!
